Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Insights into the Surface Chemistry of Water Oxidation on Pure and Modified Hematite Surfaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
SusChEM: Insights into the Surface Chemistry of Water Oxidation on Pure and Modified Hematite Surfaces

Solutions for supplying sustainable energy, in particular our demand for fuels, will likely require developments in photoelectrocatalysis that enable us to go beyond only electricity generation. Hematite (iron oxide)-based materials are promising for water oxidation using sunlight, a reaction that currently limits performance in photoelectrocatalytic devices for generating hydrogen from water splitting or hydrocarbon fuel from carbon dioxide reduction. Iron oxide is an attractive photoelectrode material because it absorbs 40% of the solar spectrum, and is cheap, abundant, nontoxic, and stable against corrosion. Iron oxide is also very inefficient for energy conversion. This can be addressed by modifying the surface with other materials to improve performance. This project aims to develop a fundamental understanding of the surface chemistry of water oxidation on pure and modified hematite surfaces, which aid the development of new materials and future solar-driven photocatalytic devices. The work involves graduate and undergraduate students and postdoctoral research associates learning and collaborating on cutting-edge approaches in chemistry, surface science, and nanotechnology for discovering new catalysts and advancing sustainable energy production. The research results are integrated into undergraduate and graduate courses and undergraduate and K-12 educational outreach programs.

With this award, the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division funds Dr. Bruce Koel of Princeton University to study the fundamental surface chemistry and processes associated with water oxidation on hematite (alpha-Fe2O3)-based photoanodes. The efficiency of this reaction must be increased to enable several transformative solar fuel production technologies to be utilized for future sustainable energy production. Iron oxide is attractive because of its solar absorption spectrum and abundance, but it is very inefficient. One strategy is to improve reaction kinetics and overpotentials by surface modifications with co-catalysts or by doping. Dr. Koel and his group establish composition-activity relationships on well-defined pure and modified single crystal alpha-Fe2O3 electrodes, with heteroatoms localized at the surface and subsurface. They also experimentally identify and characterize surface-bound species in order to investigate key aspects of the water oxidation mechanism. Measurements include using in operando techniques in which the electrode surface is probed during oxidation rate measurements. Insights provided by this work benefit the rational design of nanostructured catalysts and their applications in energy conversion. This is a Sustainable Chemistry, Engineering & Materials (SusChEM) proposal.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Addressing the energy needs of the US and the world is the science and engineering challenge of the 21st century. Solutions will require large mobilization and investments in research and development in a number of energy-related technologies. Solar fuel technologies are expected to play a major role and a greater understanding of photocatalysis on both fundamental and practical levels can provide a rational basis for the advances and discoveries of new materials and processes that are needed to realize this potential.

In the various proposed schemes for solar fuels, including carbon dioxide (CO2) reduction for hydrocarbon production and the splitting of water (H2O) for hydrogen (H2) production, a critical technological hurdle is to efficiently drive the accompanying reaction of water oxidation, or oxygen evolution reaction (OER), in which oxygen (O2) is produced. Heterogeneous catalysts for this reaction often involve transition metal oxides. During this grant, Bruce Koel and his team have conducted fundamental studies of surface chemistry and atomic scale investigations of reaction sites associated with water oxidation on hematite (α-Fe2O3)-based photoanodes, along with other electrocatalyst materials. Experiments were conducted that established composition/structure-activity relationships on well-defined pure and modified single crystals, nanomaterials, and thin films of catalysts, and experimentally identified and characterized surface-bound species in order to investigate key aspects of the water oxidation mechanism.

We compared the morphology, crystal structure, chemical composition, and electrochemical properties of hematite and Ni-doped hematite nanomaterials with different relative concentrations of exposed basal plane (0001) surfaces to determine that the basal plane surfaces of α-Fe2O3 nanocrystals are preferentially activated for water oxidation by Ni doping. We also found that cobalt oxyhydroxide (CoOOH) nanowire catalysts were significantly improved through incorporation of Ni, but not Mn. Isobars at 1 torr water pressure obtained from ambient pressure photoemission spectroscopy (APPES) experiments revealed directly that the stability of OH groups was much greater on Ni-CoOOH than CoOOH, confirming our analysis of electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). Operando Raman spectroscopy was used while measuring the OER rate to observe that Ni-modified CoOxHy films underwent an irreversible transformation of a spinel local structure to an amorphous CoO structure and then a reversible change to a complex phase of NiOOH and layered CoO2 motifs (NiOOH-h-CoO2) at elevated OER rates. Formation of this structure was independent of the initial cobalt oxide structure, which suggests this could be the universally active structure for NiCoOxHy electrocatalysts.

We discovered a new OER catalyst based on cerium-modified copper oxide prepared by a facile electrodeposition procedure that had a greatly improved OER activity. A strong correlation was observed between OER performance and tetravalent Ce (Ce4+) ion concentration, up to a concentration corresponding to CeO2 phase segregation. In other related studies, we identified a highly active binary Hf-Ir oxide electrocatalyst for OER that was formed in situ on a Hf-Ir alloy surface by anodic polarization. This binary oxide demonstrated ten times greater activity than Ir oxide in alkaline conditions. We discovered that HfOOH with incorporated nitrogen by using an atmospheric nitrogen plasma demonstrated high catalytic activity and stability for both hydrogen evolution (HER) and oxidation (HOR) reactions in strong acidic media using earth-abundant materials. These results indicate that this material could be a valuable alternative for platinum as an active and stable electrocatalyst, and furthermore that nitrogen plasma treatment may be useful in activating other non-conductive materials to form new active electrocatalysts. We also discovered that while bulk gold is catalytically inactive, high coverages (> 0.6 monolayer) of Au deposited on a Pd3Fe(111) surface were highly active and stable. Balancing of activity and stability in this ternary Au-Pd/Fe electrocatalyst provides a potential candidate for non-platinum, highly stable oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) catalysts that may provide solutions for the sluggish kinetics and low durability of ORR catalysts in polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells (PEM-FCs).

The results and understanding developed during this grant are described in seven published peer-reviewed articles and one book chapter. The results have been further disseminated by 27 papers presented at scientific conferences and three seminars presented at universities. Thirteen young scholars were trained with financial support from this grant: seven undergraduates (four of whom was female), four Ph.D. students (one of whom were female), and two postdoctoral research associates. These young scientists are now in graduate school, employed in the private sector at companies, in a postdoctoral research position, while one has taken a faculty position at the University of California at Davis. Additional technical details for the expert reader regarding the accomplishments this grant made possible are available upon request.
